data.body:
Congratulations! You are the new intern at Very Good Food & Stuff Company, a business “for all of your food and stuff needs”. The chairman expects everyone to show up on time, speak honestly, and treat everyone with fairness to get along just fine. The company just started, and thanks in large part to the stewardship of the chairman, it has built a good customer base. The following is the content of the customers file (customers.txt):
type : subscribed, age :43 ,firstname: Barney ,id:313, lastname : Lewis firstname: Leslie , age :33 , lastname : Traeger,id:442, type : subscribed lastname : Varmn,firstname: Diane ,id:682, age :43 , type : casual lastname : Gergich, age :40 , type : loyal,firstname: Diane ,id:644 type : subscribed, age :45 ,id:890,firstname: Lucy , lastname : Varmn id:502, age :28 , type : casual, lastname : Lewis,firstname: Tom lastname : Malwae-Tweep, type : subscribed,id:346, age :38 ,firstname: Leslie firstname: Janet ,id:187, age :42 , type : casual, lastname : Santodomingo firstname: Ann ,id:574, lastname : Traeger, type : casual, age :36 age :25 , type : diamond,firstname: Leslie ,id:149, lastname : Dwyer id:827, type : casual, age :23 ,firstname: Garry , lastname : Wyatt firstname: Jean-Ralphio , type : loyal,id:194, lastname : Santodomingo, age :50 type : subscribed, age :34 , lastname : Newport,firstname: Tom ,id:969 firstname: Diane , type : subscribed, lastname : Gergich, age :47 ,id:857 firstname: Donna ,id:552, type : casual, age :25 , lastname : Saperstein id:373, age :33 ,firstname: Bobby , type : diamond, lastname : Gergich lastname : Knope, age :38 ,firstname: Shauna , type : casual,id:588 type : loyal, lastname : Dwyer, age :34 ,id:538,firstname: Leslie type : casual,id:169, age :22 , lastname : Wyatt,firstname: Diane age :36 , lastname : Saperstein,id:671, type : loyal,firstname: Diane
Every line in the file is the data of a customer stored as four name:value pairs separated by comma. Pair keys are firstname, lastname, age, id, and type. Pairs appear shuffled in each line of the file, and with extra space characters all over the place, but the content is correct. Your main task is to understand the code base. The first function to consider is customerData, which transforms a string of data (as found in the customers file) and returns a dictionary with the respective customer attributes. Andy Dwyer, your manager (completely oblivious about Python, yet well intended) has some claims about the code base in general. You need to avoid a system collapsing due to the manager’s lack of knowledge! Ethel Beavers, the chairman’s secretary, says that using a set to store the customers’ attributes will simplify her work. Should you comply with her request?

answerChoices.body: Yes, since we can associate keys to the items in a set.
No, since each customer’s value has an associated key, and we need to store both.
Yes, since the keys are unique, and therefore we can access each item unequivocally in a set.
No, since sets do not preserve the ordering of the data.

data.content:
def customerData(data):
    dataList = data.split(",")
    dataDict = dict()
    
    for entry in dataList:
        key, value = entry.split(":")
        key = key.strip()
        value = value.strip()
        dataDict[key] = value
    
    return dataDict
